entry.et: Middle English wolle, from Old English wull; akin to Old High German wolla wool, Latin vellus fleece, lana wool

def.dt: :the soft wavy or curly usually thick undercoat of various hairy mammals and especially the sheep made up of a matrix of keratin fibers and covered with minute scales
:a woven fabric or garment of such fabric
:a dense felted pubescence especially on a plant :tomentum
:a filamentous mass usually used in combination compare mineral wool steel wool
:a fatty slightly sticky wax coating the surface of the fibers of sheep's wool compare wool fat
:long-staple strong-fibered wool found suitable for combing and used especially in the manufacture of worsteds
:glass fibers in a mass resembling wool and being used especially for thermal insulation and air filters
:any of various lightweight vitreous fibrous materials used especially in heat and sound insulation
:mineral wool made by blowing a jet of steam through molten rock (as limestone or siliceous rock) or through slag and used chiefly for heat and sound insulation
:fine wool from sheep raised in the Shetland Islands
